content: Yes, it does reduce the amount of airborne fibers. But, it is still Class 1 removal due to the fact that you have to scrap it off with either a mutt or hand scraper. That requires air-testing, containment, airlock w/ shower, donning of Tyvek suits, notification (EPA guideline), and the use of PAPR until air sampling verifies fiber count per cubic centimeter. If it is below 10 fcc, then you can downgrade your respirator to a half-face respirator. Also, all respirators must use P100 filters. You can't go using a paper dust mask, that is for sure. Popcorn ceiling is a pain in the arse to remove. Not because of the difficulty of removal, but because of the regulations involved. Popcorn ceilings usually have 30% or more asbestos in it. Just to give a comparison, the asbo "mag" used to cover industrial hot piping usually only contains 15%. Asbo floor tile usually contains 2-5%, but is non-friable. So, about the only asbo that a homeowner could realistically remove themselves is floor tile. It still requires the use of water, respirators and other PPE, as well as notification. But, you don't need to use a containment. So, popcorn ceilings are usually best kept and undisturbed. You may even want to encapsulate it to add relief to any worry.

content: Yes, it does reduce the amount of airborne fibers. But, it is still Class 1 removal due to the fact that you have to scrap it off with either a mutt or hand scraper. That requires air-testing, containment, airlock w/ shower, donning of Tyvek suits, notification (EPA guideline), and the use of PAPR until air sampling verifies fiber count per cubic centimeter. If it is below 10 fcc, then you can downgrade your respirator to a half-face respirator. Also, all respirators must use P100 filters. You can't go using a paper dust mask, that is for sure. Popcorn ceiling is a pain in the arse to remove. Not because of the difficulty of removal, but because of the regulations involved. Popcorn ceilings usually have 30% or more asbestos in it. Just to give a comparison, the asbo "mag" used to cover industrial hot piping usually only contains 15%. Asbo floor tile usually contains 2-5%, but is non-friable. So, about the only asbo that a homeowner could realistically remove themselves is floor tile. It still requires the use of water, respirators and other PPE, as well as notification. But, you don't need to use a containment. So, popcorn ceilings are usually best kept and undisturbed. You may even want to encapsulate it to add relief to any worry.
